subject: RE: [junit] How to test protected and private methods/ fields?
msgSnippet: FWIW, Test Mentor (www.silvermark.com) gives you transparent access to private and protected methods and fields regardless of which package your tests are in.
messageBody:
FWIW, Test Mentor (www.silvermark.com) gives you transparent access to
private and protected methods and fields regardless of which package your
tests are in.

> Jens Andersen wrote:
>
> > Hi all,
> >
> > First of all I have to mention that I'm pretty novice when it
> comes to use
> > JUnit for writing unittests. But I have a question which I hope
> some of you
> > can help me with - it's regarding testing private/protected
> methods and how
> > to organize my test package.
> >
> > First the package. I have read to articles regarding test ("Junit best
> > practices" from JavaWorld and "Incremental development with Ant
> and JUnit"
> > from developerWorks). In the JBT article Andy Schneider advice
> you to keep
> > tests in the same location as the source code. And in the Incremental...
> > article Malcolm Davis advice you to make a separate package.
> Which approach
> > is the best to use?
> >
>
> it is better to make separate package. when we can identify as
> two separate
> components like source code and test code it is better to keep them as two
> different components from configuration management point of view.
>
> >
> > I must admit that I like the idea of making a separate package but then
> > again - how do I then test private and protected methods? And
> if I keep the
> > tests in the same location as the source code - who do I then
> test private
> > methods?
> >
>
> we cant test private and protected methods directly.
> we need to find the public methods, which are using those
> protected and private
> methods and test that public methods is enough. Still it is not
> sufficient.
>
> one thing the developer can do is, he can change the private and
> protected to
> public and test them. after that he can change back to private
> and protected
> respectively. but this is not that much good idea.
>
> still we need to find the exact way.
>
> >
> > I would very much appreciate if some of you could give me a
> little example
> >
> > Kind regards,
> >
> > J. Andersen
